elements.content: The structure-directing effect of counterions with different shapes and charges has been investigated in the case of the complexes formed by uranyl ions with pimelic (heptanedioic) acid (H2C7) under solvo-hydrothermal conditions. Following the previously reported isolation of one-dimensional (1D) chains with the counterions [Fe­(bipy)3]2+ and [Cu­(phen)2]+, the complex [Ni­(Me4phen)3]2­[(UO2)4­(C7)3­(NO3)6]·CH3CN (1), with a bulkier cation, was synthesized and shown to consist of molecular anionic tetranuclear uranyl species, the presence of coordinated nitrate ions preventing polymerization. 1D zigzag chains are formed in [Ag­(bipy)2]2­[UO2(C7)­(NO3)]2 (2), in which the cations, assembled into dimers through argentophilic interactions, are organized in columns through π-stacking interactions. The heterometallic complex [UO2Mn­(C7)2­(phen)2] (3) is formed in the presence of manganese­(II) cations, and it crystallizes as a two-dimensional (2D) assembly in which manganese dimers display weak antiferromagnetic coupling (J = −1.2 cm–1). Another 2D network is found in [NH4]2­[(UO2)2­(C7)3]·2H2O (4), where ammonium cations are generated in situ; in this case, parallel polycatenation of the highly convoluted 2D layers generates a 3D lattice. Finally, the complex [Co­(en)3]2­[(UO2)12­(C7)7­(O)4­(OH)8]·​2CH3CN·​3H2O (5), obtained from the same preparation as 4, crystallizes as a three-dimensional (3D) framework displaying (μ3-oxo/hydroxo)-bridged linear ribbons as secondary building units; the [Co­(en)3]3+ counterions occupy channels parallel to the ribbons and are involved in numerous hydrogen bonding interactions with uranyl oxo and carboxylate groups. Complex 3 only displays intense and well-resolved emission bands under excitation at 420 nm; the emission of complexes 1, 2, and 4 is partly quenched, the maxima positions being the same as for complex 3.

elements.content: The nature of the complexes formed in the uranyl/pimelate system depends strongly on structure-directing effects exerted by the counterions, as shown by a series of five complexes which crystallize as zero- to three-dimensional assemblies, one of them displaying parallel 2D → 3D polycatenation.
elements.clean_text: The nature of the complexes formed in the uranyl/pimelate system depends strongly on structure-directing effects exerted by the counterions, as shown by a series of five complexes which crystallize as zero- to three-dimensional assemblies, one of them displaying parallel 2D → 3D polycatenation.

elements.content: The aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylic acids of general formula HOOC–(CH2) n−2–COOH (H2Cn) are among the simplest polycarboxylic species which have been used in the synthesis of uranyl–organic coordination polymers and frameworks, and they are also probably the most conformationally flexible, particularly when compared with the more common benzene-derived ones. The first to be studied were those with short chains such as succinic (n = 4) or glutaric (n = 5) acids, while Cahill’s group later investigated the longer ones (n = 6–10), either alone or in the presence of N-donor molecules [4,4′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane, trans-1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene] which can be coligands, counterions (when protonated), or structure-inducing guests, depending, in particular, on the match between their length and that of the dicarboxylate. O-donors in the cucurbituril family have also been shown to be either coligands or guest species when associated with the 7- to 10-membered dicarboxylates. These Cn 2– ligands are typical examples of ditopic, usually divergent ligands, and they very often yield two-dimensional (2D) assemblies, although three-dimensional (3D) frameworks are also known, as well as an example of 2D → 3D entanglement. In an attempt to generate novel topologies, we recently turned to using [M­(bipy/phen)3]2+ as counterions (where M = 3d-block metal cation, bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine, and phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) in the synthesis of uranyl complexes with Cn 2– ligands (n = 7–10, 12, and 13) under solvo-hydrothermal conditions. Besides several 1D and 2D assemblies, these chiral counterions enabled the isolation of triple-stranded helicates with the 9- and 12-membered dicarboxylates, the first examples of this geometry reported in actinide chemistry, and of a complex displaying a Borromean-type entanglement for the longest chain characterized so far, n = 13. This work involved the screening of a large range of n values, the 3d-block metal-containing cations retaining the same charge and octahedral geometry (except for the distorted tetrahedral [Cu­(bipy/​phen)2]+), and it has illustrated a difference in the effect of bipy and phen ligands depending on the chain length of the associated dicarboxylate: either bipy or phen is suitable for helicate formation with C92– and C122–, respectively, whereas the reverse combinations lead to polymeric species. This points to subtle structure-directing effects being exerted by the counterions, which the present work probes further from a different perspective since a single ligand, the dianion of pimelic acid H2C7, was used (chosen so as to alleviate in some measure the extended disorder effects often associated with the longest chains), and the variations were provided by the use of different cations displaying various shapes, charges, and potential modes of interaction: [Ni­(Me4phen)3]2+ (Me4phen = 3,4,7,8-tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline), which is bulkier than the cations previously used, [Ag­(bipy)2]+, [NH4]+, and [Co­(en)3]3+ (en = ethylenediamine). Four novel complexes were thus obtained, and another one results from direct carboxylate coordination to Mn­(phen)2 2+ groups. All of them were characterized by their crystal structure and most of them by their emission spectrum in the solid state, as described herein. Only five crystal structures of uranyl pimelates are present in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.37), in addition to those recently reported. Athough the H2Cn family could appear at first sight to be a somewhat undifferentiated series, previous work on uranyl complexes has shown that modification of the chain length by only one carbon atom may result in utterly different structures, so that the present results cannot be extrapolated to even the closest members in the series. One possible reason for this is the dependence of the direction of the carboxylate groups upon parity for identical conformations (which is why the H2Cn series displays a remarkable melting point even/odd alternation), and another, particularly in the cases where the conformation of the chain is not extended (and is sometimes very tortuous indeed, so that the parity effect appears quite irrelevant), is the difference in the association with guest species or counterions through weak interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylic acids of general formula HOOC-(CH2) n-2-COOH (H2Cn) are among the simplest polycarboxylic species which have been used in the synthesis of uranyl-organic coordination polymers and frameworks, and they are also probably the most conformationally flexible, particularly when compared with the more common benzene-derived ones. The first to be studied were those with short chains such as succinic (n = 4) or glutaric (n = 5) acids, while Cahill's group later investigated the longer ones (n = 6-10), either alone or in the presence of N-donor molecules [4,4'-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene] which can be coligands, counterions (when protonated), or structure-inducing guests, depending, in particular, on the match between their length and that of the dicarboxylate. O-donors in the cucurbituril family have also been shown to be either coligands or guest species when associated with the 7- to 10-membered dicarboxylates. These Cn 2- ligands are typical examples of ditopic, usually divergent ligands, and they very often yield two-dimensional (2D) assemblies, although three-dimensional (3D) frameworks are also known, as well as an example of 2D → 3D entanglement. In an attempt to generate novel topologies, we recently turned to using [M(bipy/phen)3]2+ as counterions (where M = 3d-block metal cation, bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine, and phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) in the synthesis of uranyl complexes with Cn 2- ligands (n = 7-10, 12, and 13) under solvo-hydrothermal conditions. Besides several 1D and 2D assemblies, these chiral counterions enabled the isolation of triple-stranded helicates with the 9- and 12-membered dicarboxylates, the first examples of this geometry reported in actinide chemistry, and of a complex displaying a Borromean-type entanglement for the longest chain characterized so far, n = 13. This work involved the screening of a large range of n values, the 3d-block metal-containing cations retaining the same charge and octahedral geometry (except for the distorted tetrahedral [Cu(bipy/phen)2]+), and it has illustrated a difference in the effect of bipy and phen ligands depending on the chain length of the associated dicarboxylate: either bipy or phen is suitable for helicate formation with C92- and C122-, respectively, whereas the reverse combinations lead to polymeric species. This points to subtle structure-directing effects being exerted by the counterions, which the present work probes further from a different perspective since a single ligand, the dianion of pimelic acid H2C7, was used (chosen so as to alleviate in some measure the extended disorder effects often associated with the longest chains), and the variations were provided by the use of different cations displaying various shapes, charges, and potential modes of interaction: [Ni(Me4phen)3]2+ (Me4phen = 3,4,7,8-tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline), which is bulkier than the cations previously used, [Ag(bipy)2]+, [NH4]+, and [Co(en)3]3+ (en = ethylenediamine). Four novel complexes were thus obtained, and another one results from direct carboxylate coordination to Mn(phen)2 2+ groups. All of them were characterized by their crystal structure and most of them by their emission spectrum in the solid state, as described herein. Only five crystal structures of uranyl pimelates are present in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.37), in addition to those recently reported. Athough the H2Cn family could appear at first sight to be a somewhat undifferentiated series, previous work on uranyl complexes has shown that modification of the chain length by only one carbon atom may result in utterly different structures, so that the present results cannot be extrapolated to even the closest members in the series. One possible reason for this is the dependence of the direction of the carboxylate groups upon parity for identical conformations (which is why the H2Cn series displays a remarkable melting point even/odd alternation), and another, particularly in the cases where the conformation of the chain is not extended (and is sometimes very tortuous indeed, so that the parity effect appears quite irrelevant), is the difference in the association with guest species or counterions through weak interactions.

Caution! Uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, and uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (depleted uranium, R. P. Normapur, 99%), AgNO3, and Ni­(NO3)2·​6H2O were purchased from Prolabo; Mn­(NO3)2·​4H2O was from Merck; [Co­(en)3]­Cl3·​3H2O was from Alfa-Aesar; 2,2′-bipyridine (bipy) was from Fluka; and pimelic acid (H2C7), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and 3,4,7,8-tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (Me4phen) were from Aldrich. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. at Chobham, U.K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

  Caution!  Uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, and uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (depleted uranium, R. P. Normapur, 99%), AgNO3, and Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O were purchased from Prolabo; Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O was from Merck; [Co(en)3]Cl3⋅3H2O was from Alfa-Aesar; 2,2'-bipyridine (bipy) was from Fluka; and pimelic acid (H2C7), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and 3,4,7,8-tetramethyl-1,10-phenanthroline (Me4phen) were from Aldrich. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. at Chobham, U.K.

elements.content: H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), Ni­(NO3)2·​6H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Me4phen (24 mg, 0.10 mmol), CH3CN (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving light pink crystals of complex 1 within 1 week. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (9 mg, 15% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C119H129­N19Ni2­O38U4: C, 40.80; H, 3.71; N, 7.60. Found: C, 41.01; H, 3.55; N, 7.54%.

elements.content: H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), [Co­(en)3]­Cl3·​3H2O (12 mg, 0.03 mmol), CH3CN (0.20 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving predominantly large, brick-shaped light yellow crystals of complex 4 mixed with a small amount of very small, lath-shaped darker yellow crystals of complex 5 within 1 month. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (11 mg, 29% yield based on U if only complex 4 is considered). Anal. Calcd for complex 4, C21H42­N2­O18U2: C, 23.21; H, 3.90; N, 2.58. Found: C, 23.97; H, 3.69; N, 3.63%. The discrepancy in nitrogen content may be due in part to the presence of the small amount of complex 5.

elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protective coating of Paratone-N oil (Hampton Research). The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans with a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by intrinsic phasing with SHELXT, expanded by subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms were retrieved from difference Fourier maps when possible, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom (1.5 for CH3, with optimized geometry). Special details are as follows.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protective coating of Paratone-N oil (Hampton Research). The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans with a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by intrinsic phasing with SHELXT, expanded by subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen and nitrogen atoms were retrieved from difference Fourier maps when possible, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom (1.5 for CH3, with optimized geometry). Special details are as follows.

elements.content: Restraints on bond lengths and displacement parameters were applied for part of an aliphatic chain and the solvent acetonitrile molecule. Twinning of the crystal with [1 0 0] as two-fold rotation twin axis was detected with PLATON/TwinRotMat and taken into account.
elements.clean_text:
Complex 1 

Restraints on bond lengths and displacement parameters were applied for part of an aliphatic chain and the solvent acetonitrile molecule. Twinning of the crystal with [1 0 0] as two-fold rotation twin axis was detected with PLATON/TwinRotMat and taken into account.

elements.content: One carbon atom (C5) is disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity. One solvent water molecule (O18) is also disordered over two positions. Restraints on some bond lengths, angles, and displacement parameters were applied for the atoms in the disordered part and in part of a second aliphatic chain which is probably affected by unresolved disorder. The hydrogen atoms bound to N1, N2, and O17 were found on a difference Fourier map, but not those of the disordered water molecule. The refined Flack parameter is 0.003(13).
elements.clean_text:
Complex 4 

One carbon atom (C5) is disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity. One solvent water molecule (O18) is also disordered over two positions. Restraints on some bond lengths, angles, and displacement parameters were applied for the atoms in the disordered part and in part of a second aliphatic chain which is probably affected by unresolved disorder. The hydrogen atoms bound to N1, N2, and O17 were found on a difference Fourier map, but not those of the disordered water molecule. The refined Flack parameter is 0.003(13).

elements.content: One of the dicarboxylate ligands is disordered over two positions with the central atom C25 located on an inversion center, and one complete molecule was refined with an occupancy parameter of 0.5. Atoms O25 and O27 being nearly equivalent, O27 had to be fixed during the last refinement cycles, and restraints on bond lengths, angles, and displacement parameters had to be applied for all atoms in this molecule. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters had also to be applied for some atoms in other badly behaving parts (one aliphatic chain and one ethylenediamine ligand). One water solvent molecule was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 in order to retain an acceptable displacement parameter. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on a difference Fourier map, and all the others were introduced at calculated positions.
elements.clean_text:
Complex 5 

One of the dicarboxylate ligands is disordered over two positions with the central atom C25 located on an inversion center, and one complete molecule was refined with an occupancy parameter of 0.5. Atoms O25 and O27 being nearly equivalent, O27 had to be fixed during the last refinement cycles, and restraints on bond lengths, angles, and displacement parameters had to be applied for all atoms in this molecule. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters had also to be applied for some atoms in other badly behaving parts (one aliphatic chain and one ethylenediamine ligand). One water solvent molecule was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 in order to retain an acceptable displacement parameter. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on a difference Fourier map, and all the others were introduced at calculated positions.

Emission spectra were recorded on solid samples using a Horiba-Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog spectrofluorometer. The powdered complex was pressed between two silica plates which were mounted such that the faces were oriented vertically and at 45° to the incident excitation radiation. An excitation wavelength of 420 nm was used in all cases, and the emissions were monitored between 450 and 650 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

Emission spectra were recorded on solid samples using a Horiba-Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog spectrofluorometer. The powdered complex was pressed between two silica plates which were mounted such that the faces were oriented vertically and at 45° to the incident excitation radiation. An excitation wavelength of 420 nm was used in all cases, and the emissions were monitored between 450 and 650 nm.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements on a powder sample of complex 3 were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID Magnetometer with an applied field of 1000 G. The independence of the susceptibility value with regard to the applied field was checked at room temperature. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions as calculated from tables of Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Magnetic measurements on a powder sample of complex 3 were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID Magnetometer with an applied field of 1000 G. The independence of the susceptibility value with regard to the applied field was checked at room temperature. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions as calculated from tables of Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Complexes 1–5 were all obtained under solvo-hydrothermal conditions. However, while the organic solvent was N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in all our previous work with the H2Cn series, this solvent allowed the growth of crystals suitable for structure determination in the only case of compound 3 in the present series, and it had to be replaced by acetonitrile in the syntheses of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5. The 2:3 uranyl/H2Cn stoichiometry was used throughout, being the one associated with honeycomb 2D lattices such as those formerly obtained with H2C10 and H2C12; no network with this topology was, however, obtained. The crystalline materials deposited during the heating phase (140 °C). In all cases, the diacid is fully deprotonated in the final product. The optimization of procedures in solvothermal syntheses often involves a compromise between multiple influences and is necessarily somewhat empirical due to the lack of detailed thermodynamic data for the systems involved. In the present work, numerous alternatives were investigated but only those leading to successful deposition of crystalline material are described.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Complexes 1-5 were all obtained under solvo-hydrothermal conditions. However, while the organic solvent was N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in all our previous work with the H2Cn series, this solvent allowed the growth of crystals suitable for structure determination in the only case of compound 3 in the present series, and it had to be replaced by acetonitrile in the syntheses of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5. The 2:3 uranyl/H2Cn stoichiometry was used throughout, being the one associated with honeycomb 2D lattices such as those formerly obtained with H2C10 and H2C12; no network with this topology was, however, obtained. The crystalline materials deposited during the heating phase (140 °C). In all cases, the diacid is fully deprotonated in the final product. The optimization of procedures in solvothermal syntheses often involves a compromise between multiple influences and is necessarily somewhat empirical due to the lack of detailed thermodynamic data for the systems involved. In the present work, numerous alternatives were investigated but only those leading to successful deposition of crystalline material are described.

elements.content: Crystals of complexes 4 and 5 were obtained together from the same solution, and they can be easily differentiated through their very different shapes (and in a lesser measure their colors). Compound 4 was predominant, crystals of 5 being much less numerous and very small. The ammonium counterions present in 4 may originate from two sources, either the acetonitrile solvent or ethylenediamine; the first pathway, operating through hydrolysis catalyzed by uranium­(VI), appears to be more probable than the second, which would necessitate oxidation into an imine, followed by hydrolysis, although it has previously been shown to occur under hydrothermal conditions. While complex 5 contains the expected [Co­(en)3]3+ counterion, also present are oxo and hydroxo anions resulting from hydrolysis and leading to the formation of secondary building units, as frequently experienced in uranyl chemistry. The fact that these two different complexes deposited from the same solution is indicative of the multiplicity of species that may be present in the mother liquors as well as of the importance of the counterion.

elements.content: The complex [Ni­(Me4phen)3]2­[(UO2)4­(C7)3­(NO3)6]·​CH3CN (1) is peculiar in being a molecular, and not a polymeric, species. Apart from the helicates recently reported, molecular species are not very numerous among uranyl complexes with Cn 2– anions. The asymmetric unit in 1 contains four independent uranyl ions connected to one another by three C72– anions to form an open chain (). Each of the terminal uranium atoms, U1 and U4, is chelated by one carboxylate group and two nitrate ions, whereas each of the central atoms, U2 and U3, is chelated by two carboxylate and one nitrate groups, all being in hexagonal bipyramidal environments. The U–O­(carboxylate) and U–O­(nitrate) bond lengths are in the ranges 2.413(6)–2.495(7) Å [average 2.44(2) Å] and 2.479(8)–2.523(7) Å [average 2.498(14) Å], these values being unexceptional. The bis-chelating C72– anions assume very irregular conformations, with the O–C–C–C and C–C–C–C torsion angles showing different sequences of anti and gauche (or intermediate) values in the three ligands. Overall, the first and third ligands, bound to the terminal uranyl ions, are somewhat U-shaped, while the central one is extended (although irregularly so). This results in the buckled shape of the tetranuclear complex, with no even very approximate pseudo-symmetry being apparent. All the previously known complexes involving C72– anions are polymeric; in particular, the only one involving an octahedral counterion, [Fe­(bipy)3]­[(UO2)2­(C7)3]·​3H2O, crystallizes as a 1D ladder-like ribbon. Although the organic cosolvent in the synthesis of this latter compound (DMF) is different from that used here, it is assumed that the complete dissimilarity of the complexes formed is primarily a result of the bulkier counterions in 1. The tetra-anions in 1 are arranged in rows parallel to the b axis, these rows being further associated in groups of two inversion-related ones facing each other through the central ligands, as shown in (in which the Me4phen molecules are omitted for clarity). The [Ni­(Me4phen)3]2+ counterions occupy the spaces present between these groups along the a axis, and some of their methyl substituents are pointing inside the rows. They form Δ,Λ pairs through an embrace in which one ligand of each in a pair lies parallel to one of the other, although the Hirshfeld surface calculated with CrystalExplorer indicates that this involves no more than dispersion interactions. Nonetheless, these pairs form an exceptionally large cationic unit when compared to most in known similar structures and it may be this feature which explains the unusual nature of the uranate anion formed in the crystal. Notwithstanding that the interactions determining the packing are mainly Coulombic, weaker interactions can be discerned, which are possibly effective in influencing the finer details of the positioning of the different moieties. Five parallel-displaced π-stacking contacts are found between the cations [centroid···centroid distances 4.266(6)–4.648(6) Å, dihedral angle 0–6.5(5)°], being, as noted above, perhaps indicative of no more than dispersion interactions, as well as four CH···π ones, all involving aromatic or methyl hydrogen atoms of the Me4phen molecules (H···centroid distances 2.84–2.98 Å). Several short contacts are also present between uncoordinated nitrate oxygen atoms and nitrogen-containing aromatic rings [O···centroid distances 3.109(11)–3.699(13) Å, N–O···centroid angles 100.3(10)–161.5(8)°], which may be indicative of anion···π interactions, although the significance of their contribution here is very uncertain. In addition, numerous short CH­(cation)···O contacts are found down to 2.38 Å which involve either aromatic or methyl groups as donors and oxo, carboxylate, and nitrate oxygen atoms as acceptors. Such weak CH···O hydrogen bonds were previously found in this family of complexes with bipy- or phen-containing counterions.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

The complex [Ni(Me4phen)3]2[(UO2)4(C7)3(NO3)6]⋅CH3CN (1) is peculiar in being a molecular, and not a polymeric, species. Apart from the helicates recently reported, molecular species are not very numerous among uranyl complexes with Cn 2- anions. The asymmetric unit in 1 contains four independent uranyl ions connected to one another by three C72- anions to form an open chain (). Each of the terminal uranium atoms, U1 and U4, is chelated by one carboxylate group and two nitrate ions, whereas each of the central atoms, U2 and U3, is chelated by two carboxylate and one nitrate groups, all being in hexagonal bipyramidal environments. The U-O(carboxylate) and U-O(nitrate) bond lengths are in the ranges 2.413(6)-2.495(7) Å [average 2.44(2) Å] and 2.479(8)-2.523(7) Å [average 2.498(14) Å], these values being unexceptional. The bis-chelating C72- anions assume very irregular conformations, with the O-C-C-C and C-C-C-C torsion angles showing different sequences of anti and gauche (or intermediate) values in the three ligands. Overall, the first and third ligands, bound to the terminal uranyl ions, are somewhat U-shaped, while the central one is extended (although irregularly so). This results in the buckled shape of the tetranuclear complex, with no even very approximate pseudo-symmetry being apparent. All the previously known complexes involving C72- anions are polymeric; in particular, the only one involving an octahedral counterion, [Fe(bipy)3][(UO2)2(C7)3]⋅3H2O, crystallizes as a 1D ladder-like ribbon. Although the organic cosolvent in the synthesis of this latter compound (DMF) is different from that used here, it is assumed that the complete dissimilarity of the complexes formed is primarily a result of the bulkier counterions in 1. The tetra-anions in 1 are arranged in rows parallel to the b axis, these rows being further associated in groups of two inversion-related ones facing each other through the central ligands, as shown in  (in which the Me4phen molecules are omitted for clarity). The [Ni(Me4phen)3]2+ counterions occupy the spaces present between these groups along the a axis, and some of their methyl substituents are pointing inside the rows. They form Δ,Λ pairs through an embrace in which one ligand of each in a pair lies parallel to one of the other, although the Hirshfeld surface calculated with CrystalExplorer indicates that this involves no more than dispersion interactions. Nonetheless, these pairs form an exceptionally large cationic unit when compared to most in known similar structures and it may be this feature which explains the unusual nature of the uranate anion formed in the crystal. Notwithstanding that the interactions determining the packing are mainly Coulombic, weaker interactions can be discerned, which are possibly effective in influencing the finer details of the positioning of the different moieties. Five parallel-displaced π-stacking contacts are found between the cations [centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distances 4.266(6)-4.648(6) Å, dihedral angle 0-6.5(5)°], being, as noted above, perhaps indicative of no more than dispersion interactions, as well as four CH⋅⋅⋅π ones, all involving aromatic or methyl hydrogen atoms of the Me4phen molecules (H⋅⋅⋅centroid distances 2.84-2.98 Å). Several short contacts are also present between uncoordinated nitrate oxygen atoms and nitrogen-containing aromatic rings [O⋅⋅⋅centroid distances 3.109(11)-3.699(13) Å, N-O⋅⋅⋅centroid angles 100.3(10)-161.5(8)°], which may be indicative of anion⋅⋅⋅π interactions, although the significance of their contribution here is very uncertain. In addition, numerous short CH(cation)⋅⋅⋅O contacts are found down to 2.38 Å which involve either aromatic or methyl groups as donors and oxo, carboxylate, and nitrate oxygen atoms as acceptors. Such weak CH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds were previously found in this family of complexes with bipy- or phen-containing counterions.

elements.content: Top: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. The counterion, solvent molecule, and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Middle: View of four tetranuclear anions arranged in a row along the b axis. Bottom: View of the packing with the Me4phen ligands, solvent molecules, and hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity. Uranium coordination polyhedra are colored yellow, and nickel­(II) cations are shown as blue spheres.

elements.content: Complex 2, [Ag­(bipy)2]2­[UO2­(C7)­(NO3)]2, crystallizes with one uranyl and one silver­(I) cation in the asymmetric unit. The uranyl cation is chelated by two carboxylate groups and one nitrate ion, the latter being a feature in common with complex 1 (). The U–O­(carboxylate) bond lengths are in the range 2.413(2)–2.480(2) Å [average 2.45(2) Å], and the U–O­(nitrate) bond lengths are 2.539(2) and 2.547(2) Å. The bis-chelating C72– anion is in a regular, nearly planar extended conformation, with all C–C–C–C torsion angles being anti and the O–C–C–C ones anti or syn. The 1D polymers formed run along the b axis and assume a zigzag shape due to the cis position of the carboxylates in the uranyl equatorial plane. These chains are packed so as to define channels directed along the a axis, in which the counterions are located. The latter are centrosymmetric {[Ag­(bipy)2]2}2+ dimers with a Ag–Ag separation of 3.3262(5) Å, slightly shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of silver (1.72 Å), and thus indicative of a weak argentophilic interaction. This is not, however, a particularly short distance since values smaller than ∼3.15 Å are common and even a distance of 2.72 Å has been reported. The Ag­(bipy)2 moiety, with Ag–N bond lengths of 2.312(3)–2.468(2) Å [average 2.39(7) Å, consistent with the average value of 2.35(11) Å from the CSD], is nearly planar, with a root-mean-square (rms) deviation of 0.098 Å for the N4 plane, and Ag1 is displaced by 0.1304(13) Å from this plane, on the same side as the second silver ion. The two Ag­(bipy)2 units are offset with respect to one another, with an angle of 148.8° between the N4 planes and the Ag–Ag line. The four bipy molecules in the dimer are involved in six parallel-displaced π-stacking interactions, while six more link each dimer to its neighbors along the a axis [centroid···centroid distances 3.6221(18)–4.8280(19) Å, dihedral angle 0–15.29(15)°], thus resulting in the formation of columns with an alternation of short and long [6.1144(5) Å] Ag···Ag separations. Only one possibly significant CH­(aliphatic)···π contact is present [H···centroid distance 2.66 Å, C–H···centroid angle 168°], and several CH­(aromatic)···O short contacts (down to 2.40 Å) may indicate weak hydrogen bonding. Among the carboxylate complexes containing both uranyl and silver­(I) cations reported in the CSD, most are heterometallic complexes in which silver is bound to a carboxylate group or a nitrogen donor pertaining to the same ligand, and only in one case is a [Ag­(bipy)2]+ counterion of distorted tetrahedral geometry present. We found recently that columns of [Ag­(bipy)2]+ counterions are also formed in the uranyl complex with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate and induce in this case the formation of a 2D → 3D polycatenated system.

The Ag(bipy)2 moiety, with Ag-N bond lengths of 2.312(3)-2.468(2) Å [average 2.39(7) Å, consistent with the average value of 2.35(11) Å from the CSD], is nearly planar, with a root-mean-square (rms) deviation of 0.098 Å for the N4 plane, and Ag1 is displaced by 0.1304(13) Å from this plane, on the same side as the second silver ion. The two Ag(bipy)2 units are offset with respect to one another, with an angle of 148.8° between the N4 planes and the Ag-Ag line. The four bipy molecules in the dimer are involved in six parallel-displaced π-stacking interactions, while six more link each dimer to its neighbors along the a axis [centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distances 3.6221(18)-4.8280(19) Å, dihedral angle 0-15.29(15)°], thus resulting in the formation of columns with an alternation of short and long [6.1144(5) Å] Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separations. Only one possibly significant CH(aliphatic)⋅⋅⋅π contact is present [H⋅⋅⋅centroid distance 2.66 Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅centroid angle 168°], and several CH(aromatic)⋅⋅⋅O short contacts (down to 2.40 Å) may indicate weak hydrogen bonding. Among the carboxylate complexes containing both uranyl and silver(I) cations reported in the CSD, most are heterometallic complexes in which silver is bound to a carboxylate group or a nitrogen donor pertaining to the same ligand, and only in one case is a [Ag(bipy)2]+ counterion of distorted tetrahedral geometry present. We found recently that columns of [Ag(bipy)2]+ counterions are also formed in the uranyl complex with 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate and induce in this case the formation of a 2D → 3D polycatenated system.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit in [UO2Mn­(C7)2­(phen)2] (3) contains one uranyl and one manganese­(II) cation that, in contrast to the two preceding cases, are both part of a neutral heterometallic coordination polymer (). The uranium atom is chelated by three carboxylate groups with U–O bond lengths in the range 2.4372(14)–2.5085(14) Å [average 2.47(2) Å]. The manganese cation is chelated by two nearly orthogonal phen molecules [Mn–N bond lengths in the range 2.2826(16)–2.2986(17) Å, average 2.291(6) Å; dihedral angle 86.49(2)°]; two carboxylate oxygen atoms [Mn–O, 2.0881(15) and 2.1251(13) Å; O–Mn–O, 104.14(6)°] complete the coordination sphere to give a distorted cis-N4O2 octahedral environment, as commonly observed for Mn­(II). The carboxylate group bound to the manganese atom being bridging bidentate, a centrosymmetric dimeric subunit is formed, with a Mn···Mn separation of 4.6169(6) Å; more than 30 examples of comparable manganese dimers with bipy or phen donors and bridging carboxylates are found in the CSD, with an average Mn···Mn separation of 4.70(16) Å. An analogous geometry was also found in the uranyl–manganese heterometallic complex with C132–, while a molecular complex with a terminal Mn­(phen)2 group bound to a chelating carboxylate is present in the complex with C82–. In the whole series of Cn 2– complexes obtained up to now, Mn­(II) (and in one case Co­(II) as well) is notable for its tendency to exchange one of the three bipy/phen ligands generally found with Fe­(II) or Ni­(II) cations for two carboxylate donors. One C72– anion in 3 is bis-chelating and connects two uranium atoms, and the other is bound to one uranium and two manganese ions in chelating/bridging bidentate fashion. Both of them display quite irregular conformations, with different sequences of anti and gauche (or intermediate) values for the O–C–C–C and C–C–C–C torsion angles. As a result of this connectivity, a 2D assembly parallel to (1 0 2̅) is formed, with the point (Schläfli) symbol {103} if only uranium atoms are considered as nodes (the manganese dimer being a simple link). These layers are planar, but they can be seen as formed of two heterometallic layers and they have a substantial thickness of ∼14 Å (between the outermost phen atoms). No contact indicative of π-stacking interactions is found, as a result of the layers being packed in bump-to-hollow fashion with no close approach of the protruding phen groups, but two CH­(aliphatic)···π ones are present [H···centroid distances 2.81 and 2.86 Å, C–H···centroid angle 135° for both]. As in complexes 1 and 2, several CH­(aromatic)···O short contacts (down to 2.39 Å) may indicate weak hydrogen bonding involving both oxo and carboxylate acceptors.

elements.content: Complex 4, [NH4]2­[(UO2)2­(C7)3]·​2H2O, is the only one in this series not to contain metallic counterions, these being replaced by ammonium cations generated in situ (complex 5, obtained from the same batch, includes the expected cobalt-containing cations). Compound 4 crystallizes in the Sohncke group P212121, with two independent uranium atoms in the asymmetric unit (). Both of them are chelated by three carboxylate groups, with U–O bond lengths in the range 2.440(8)–2.508(8) Å [average 2.468(17) Å]. The three independent C72– ligands have different conformations: the first (O5–O8) is mostly regularly extended, but kinked at one end, while the other two correspond to different mixtures of anti and gauche C–C–C–C torsion angles. The 2D polymeric assembly formed, perpendicular to the b axis and with the {82.10} point symbol, is shown in . It is built from three families of chains, a central one running along the c axis and two lateral ones, on either side of the former, directed along the a axis, the central one being connected to the lateral ones by bridges parallel to b. This architecture can be viewed as a trilayer, akin to the bilayer type but with the chains directed along one of the axes located on both sides of the other set, instead of on one side only. It is notable that a bilayer arrangement was found in the complex [H2BPE]­[(UO2)2­(C7)3] (BPE = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane), reported by Borkowski and Cahill, and interdigitation of the layers occurs in this case. The different topology of complex 4 and possibly also the replacement of the large H2BPE2+ cation by the much smaller NH4 + result in parallel 2D → 3D polycatenation of the trilayers: each layer is interwoven with its two neighbors to give a 3D framework, as shown in the nodal representations of . Entangled nets are not very common in uranyl structural chemistry, although about a dozen examples are known, several of them having been reported very recently. These structures display either interpenetration (with no dimensionality increase) or polycatenation (resulting assembly of higher dimensionality than its parts), with different topological types: parallel 2D → 2D, three-fold 3D, two- or three-fold inclined 2D → 3D, or three-fold parallel 2D Borromean. Complex 4 provides an example of a topology hitherto unobserved in this series, in which parallel 2D layers are polycatenated into a 3D architecture, an arrangement that is rather usual for thick layers (those whose projection on a plane necessarily involves superposition of parts), while planar nets are more likely to give 2D → 2D interpenetration or inclined 2D → 3D polycatenation. The two NH4 + counterions and the water solvent molecules in 4 are involved in many hydrogen bonds with the carboxylate oxygen atoms which further connect each layer to its neighbors.

elements.content: Complex 5, [Co­(en)3]2­[(UO2)12­(C7)7­(O)4­(OH)8]·​2CH3CN·​3H2O, is the only one in this series to contain uranyl secondary building units formed around bridging oxo and hydroxo ions resulting from hydrolysis. The asymmetric unit contains six independent uranyl ions, three complete C72– ligands, and one having inversion symmetry (and being disordered around the inversion center: see the ). All six uranyl ions are in similar five-coordinated equatorial environments consisting of two carboxylate, one μ3-oxo, and two μ3-hydroxo oxygen atoms, with, in all cases, the two carboxylate groups adjacent in the plane (). The U–O bond lengths are in the ranges 2.328(10)–2.533(16) Å [average 2.40(7) Å] for carboxylate, 2.214(8)–2.245(8) Å [average 2.228(10) Å] for oxo, and 2.417(7)–2.514(7) Å [average 2.47(3) Å] for hydroxo groups, all these values being unexceptional. Oxo/hydroxo bridging results in the formation of a 1D ribbon-like subunit running parallel to the a axis with its broader dimension in the c direction, in which adjacent uranium coordination polyhedra share either two or three edges, a usual arrangement in uranyl chains. The C72– ligands display a variety of coordination modes unseen up to now in this series, either bis­(bridging bidentate), bridging bidentate/bidentate (the latter, simple bidentate mode involving only one oxygen atom), bis­(bidentate), or bridging bidentate/uncoordinated, but none is chelating. When viewed down the chain axis, the three ligands which are coordinated at both ends point laterally, above and below the plane of the ribbons, while the uncoordinated carboxylate group approximately straddles this plane. Three ligands have either an extended conformation (with, however, rotation of one carboxylate group out of the mean plane) or a shape kinked at one end, while the last, disordered one, has a very irregular geometry with C–C–C–C torsion angles being anti, gauche, or intermediate. The ribbons are thus connected to one another by the C72– ligands to give a 3D framework displaying channels directed along the a axis. The latter are occupied by the counterions, the uncoordinated carboxylate strands, and the solvent molecules. An intricate array of hydrogen bonds connects all of these components, as expected from the hydrogen bonding proclivities of the [Co­(en)3]3+ cation. The latter, in its lel 2 ob conformation, forms a rather familiar hydrogen bond chelate of the pendent uncoordinated carboxylate unit. It is also involved in hydrogen bonding to several uranyl oxo centers, on both sides of the channel, thus playing a substantial role in the lattice assembly.

elements.content: Emission spectra under excitation at a wavelength of 420 nm, a value suitable for uranyl excitation and corresponding to the UO axial LMCT band, were recorded in the solid state for all compounds but 5, which could not be obtained as a pure phase, and the spectra are shown in . Uranyl emission is characterized by the vibronic progression corresponding to the S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 0ν (ν = 0–4) states. Among complexes 1–4, 3 only displays an intense and well-resolved spectrum, with emission maxima at 462 (w), 480 (s), 499 (s), 521 (s), 544 (m), and ∼571 (w) nm, corresponding to vibronic splitting energies for the S 10 → S 0ν transitions in the range 793–869 cm–1, to be compared with the value of 852 cm–1 in uranyl malonates. These maxima positions depend on several factors, in particular the number and nature of equatorial donors. The present values in complex 3, in which all uranyl ions have six equatorial O-donors, are very close to those found in other complexes with six carboxylate O-donors, and they are blue-shifted by ∼8 nm with respect to values in related complexes with five O-donors (in most cases, these complexes have closely related carboxylate ligands and the spectra have been measured under similar conditions). The emission is much less intense for complexes 1, 2, and 4, which is possibly due, in the two former cases, to partial quenching by transition metal cations, probably through energy transfer to the d–d excited state, followed by nonradiative decay, as is often observed. When visible, the emission maxima for compounds 2 and 4 are located at the same wavelengths as those of complex 3, and they are red-shifted by 3 nm in the case of compound 1, all of these values being thus in agreement with the six-coordinate equatorial environment found in all of these complexes.

Luminescence Properties

Emission spectra under excitation at a wavelength of 420 nm, a value suitable for uranyl excitation and corresponding to the UO axial LMCT band, were recorded in the solid state for all compounds but 5, which could not be obtained as a pure phase, and the spectra are shown in . Uranyl emission is characterized by the vibronic progression corresponding to the S 11 → S 00 and S 10 → S 0ν (ν = 0-4) states. Among complexes 1-4, 3 only displays an intense and well-resolved spectrum, with emission maxima at 462 (w), 480 (s), 499 (s), 521 (s), 544 (m), and ~571 (w) nm, corresponding to vibronic splitting energies for the S 10 → S 0ν transitions in the range 793-869 cm-1, to be compared with the value of 852 cm-1 in uranyl malonates. These maxima positions depend on several factors, in particular the number and nature of equatorial donors. The present values in complex 3, in which all uranyl ions have six equatorial O-donors, are very close to those found in other complexes with six carboxylate O-donors, and they are blue-shifted by ~8 nm with respect to values in related complexes with five O-donors (in most cases, these complexes have closely related carboxylate ligands and the spectra have been measured under similar conditions). The emission is much less intense for complexes 1, 2, and 4, which is possibly due, in the two former cases, to partial quenching by transition metal cations, probably through energy transfer to the d-d excited state, followed by nonradiative decay, as is often observed. When visible, the emission maxima for compounds 2 and 4 are located at the same wavelengths as those of complex 3, and they are red-shifted by 3 nm in the case of compound 1, all of these values being thus in agreement with the six-coordinate equatorial environment found in all of these complexes.

elements.content: Complex 3 is the only one in this series for which magnetic properties have been investigated, since no magnetic interaction is expected between the Ni2+ or Co3+ cations in complexes 1 and 5, respectively. The magnetic properties of complex 3 are those of a dicarboxylato-bridged MnII dimer. The temperature dependence of χM and χM T (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per MnII ion) has been investigated in the 2–300 K range (). At room temperature, χM T is equal to 4.4 cm3 mol–1 K, a value consistent with noninteracting MnII ions (χM T = 4.374 cm3 mol–1 K with g = 2.0). When the temperature is lowered, the χM T value remains constant until 75 K, and it then decreases to 0.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The χM value increases on decreasing the temperature from 300 K, and it presents a maximum at 5 K. The shape of these curves is indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the MnII ions. The data were fitted with a simple dimer model where the exchange is represented by the spin Hamiltonian H = −J S 1 S 2. The best fit corresponds to J = −1.2 cm–1 and g = 2.03 [R χT = 9.2 × 10–5 and R χ = 2.0 × 10–4, where R χT = ∑(χcal T – χexp T)2/​∑(χexp T)2 and R χ = ∑(χcal – χexp)2/​∑(χexp)2].

Magnetic Properties of Complex 3 

Complex 3 is the only one in this series for which magnetic properties have been investigated, since no magnetic interaction is expected between the Ni2+ or Co3+ cations in complexes 1 and 5, respectively. The magnetic properties of complex 3 are those of a dicarboxylato-bridged MnII dimer. The temperature dependence of χM and χM T (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per MnII ion) has been investigated in the 2-300 K range (). At room temperature, χM T is equal to 4.4 cm3 mol-1 K, a value consistent with noninteracting MnII ions (χM T = 4.374 cm3 mol-1 K with g = 2.0). When the temperature is lowered, the χM T value remains constant until 75 K, and it then decreases to 0.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The χM value increases on decreasing the temperature from 300 K, and it presents a maximum at 5 K. The shape of these curves is indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the MnII ions. The data were fitted with a simple dimer model where the exchange is represented by the spin Hamiltonian H = -J S 1 S 2. The best fit corresponds to J = -1.2 cm-1 and g = 2.03 [R χT  = 9.2 × 10-5 and R χ = 2.0 × 10-4, where R χT  = ∑(χcal T - χexp T)2/∑(χexp T)2 and R χ = ∑(χcal - χexp)2/∑(χexp)2].

elements.content: In general, the carboxylate group is found in a variety of bridging forms depending upon the coordination mode (syn–syn, syn–anti, anti–anti, monatomic) and the number of bridges (1–3). In complex 3, carboxylato bridges adopt a syn–syn coordination mode. This feature induces generally an antiferromagnetic coupling, the strength of which increases with the number of bridges. The J value found for complex 3 is in agreement with those reported for other complexes with double carboxylato bridges.
elements.clean_text: In general, the carboxylate group is found in a variety of bridging forms depending upon the coordination mode (syn-syn, syn-anti, anti-anti, monatomic) and the number of bridges (1-3). In complex 3, carboxylato bridges adopt a syn-syn coordination mode. This feature induces generally an antiferromagnetic coupling, the strength of which increases with the number of bridges. The J value found for complex 3 is in agreement with those reported for other complexes with double carboxylato bridges.

elements.content: The versatility of carboxylates as ligands is well-illustrated in the solid state coordination chemistry of the uranyl ion. While even a monocarboxylate species can give rise to coordination polymers involving different modes of binding, polycarboxylates are not only inherently adapted for polymer formation but also available in such a range of functionality on platforms varying from rigid to flexible that their coordination chemistry is of a truly remarkable diversity. This includes instances where coordination polymerization is avoided as a result of the formation of extremely large chelate rings fostered by the particular choice of supporting platform. In principle, all aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylates should be capable of chelation through the separate carboxylate units. Recent work has, however, shown that the solid state coordination mode of such dicarboxylates in anionic uranyl ion complexes can be strongly influenced by the choice of countercation, with what might be considered an approach to chelation resulting in the formation of capsular, binuclear helicate species rather than extended polymers. In the present work, we have thus explored further the influence of the countercation upon the coordination mode in crystalline uranyl ion complexes of the relatively short 1,7-heptanedioate (pimelate) ligand. This is a ligand of a size intermediate between those where chelation is known and those where chelation would be considered entropically highly inhibited. The structure of 1 is unusual in that while the pimelate ligands act as bridging bidentate species to link uranyl centers in a 1D array, this leads only to very limited association into a tetranuclear species. Bidentate binding of nitrate serves to truncate any lateral or linear extensions of this oligomer. The higher ratio of C72–:uranium in 2 is reflected in the presence of infinite zigzag polymer strands of pimelate-bridged uranyl units, nitrate chelation here serving only to block lateral extension of the strands into a 2D sheet. The form, charge and size of the counterions here differ from those of the cations in 1, and the Ag­(bipy)2 columns present in 2 appear as an interesting structure-directing species. Thus, the different forms of the uranyl-pimelate aggregates can be regarded as determined by the different forms of the associated cations. The structure of complex 3 provides an example of a 2D assembly where the pimelate ligands serve to bridge both uranyl and manganese centers. Complex 4 has a lattice in which highly convoluted 2D nets are polycatenated to form a 3D lattice, this entanglement being reinforced by NH···O­(carboxylate) bonding. This family of Cn 2– ligands has already given two other examples of polycatenation, and it thus appears that these long thread-like ditopic ligands are particularly suited to the formation of such topologies through formation of large rings. The 3D lattice of complex 5 provides another example of a system where the pimelate carboxylate groups are not involved exclusively in coordination to U­(VI). Here, this appears to be a consequence of the specific hydrogen bonding capacities of [Co­(en)3]3+ in that the cation forms a rather familiar hydrogen-bond chelate of one uncoordinated carboxylate unit; it is also involved in hydrogen bonding to several uranyl oxo centers, thus playing a substantial role in the lattice assembly. Such structural diversity resulting from changes in the structure-directing species is quite remarkable and appears to be a consequence of the extreme flexibility of the Cn 2– ligands, which allows the two carboxylate groups to take virtually all possible relative orientations, with a separation which is itself highly adjustable.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The versatility of carboxylates as ligands is well-illustrated in the solid state coordination chemistry of the uranyl ion. While even a monocarboxylate species can give rise to coordination polymers involving different modes of binding, polycarboxylates are not only inherently adapted for polymer formation but also available in such a range of functionality on platforms varying from rigid to flexible that their coordination chemistry is of a truly remarkable diversity. This includes instances where coordination polymerization is avoided as a result of the formation of extremely large chelate rings fostered by the particular choice of supporting platform. In principle, all aliphatic α,ω-dicarboxylates should be capable of chelation through the separate carboxylate units. Recent work has, however, shown that the solid state coordination mode of such dicarboxylates in anionic uranyl ion complexes can be strongly influenced by the choice of countercation, with what might be considered an approach to chelation resulting in the formation of capsular, binuclear helicate species rather than extended polymers. In the present work, we have thus explored further the influence of the countercation upon the coordination mode in crystalline uranyl ion complexes of the relatively short 1,7-heptanedioate (pimelate) ligand. This is a ligand of a size intermediate between those where chelation is known and those where chelation would be considered entropically highly inhibited. The structure of 1 is unusual in that while the pimelate ligands act as bridging bidentate species to link uranyl centers in a 1D array, this leads only to very limited association into a tetranuclear species. Bidentate binding of nitrate serves to truncate any lateral or linear extensions of this oligomer. The higher ratio of C72-:uranium in 2 is reflected in the presence of infinite zigzag polymer strands of pimelate-bridged uranyl units, nitrate chelation here serving only to block lateral extension of the strands into a 2D sheet. The form, charge and size of the counterions here differ from those of the cations in 1, and the Ag(bipy)2 columns present in 2 appear as an interesting structure-directing species. Thus, the different forms of the uranyl-pimelate aggregates can be regarded as determined by the different forms of the associated cations. The structure of complex 3 provides an example of a 2D assembly where the pimelate ligands serve to bridge both uranyl and manganese centers. Complex 4 has a lattice in which highly convoluted 2D nets are polycatenated to form a 3D lattice, this entanglement being reinforced by NH⋅⋅⋅O(carboxylate) bonding. This family of Cn 2- ligands has already given two other examples of polycatenation, and it thus appears that these long thread-like ditopic ligands are particularly suited to the formation of such topologies through formation of large rings. The 3D lattice of complex 5 provides another example of a system where the pimelate carboxylate groups are not involved exclusively in coordination to U(VI). Here, this appears to be a consequence of the specific hydrogen bonding capacities of [Co(en)3]3+ in that the cation forms a rather familiar hydrogen-bond chelate of one uncoordinated carboxylate unit; it is also involved in hydrogen bonding to several uranyl oxo centers, thus playing a substantial role in the lattice assembly. Such structural diversity resulting from changes in the structure-directing species is quite remarkable and appears to be a consequence of the extreme flexibility of the Cn 2- ligands, which allows the two carboxylate groups to take virtually all possible relative orientations, with a separation which is itself highly adjustable.

H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), Ni­(NO3)2·​6H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Me4phen (24 mg, 0.10 mmol), CH3CN (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving light pink crystals of complex 1 within 1 week. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (9 mg, 15% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C119H129­N19Ni2­O38U4: C, 40.80; H, 3.71; N, 7.60. Found: C, 41.01; H, 3.55; N, 7.54%.

[Ag­(bipy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[UO<sub>2</sub>(C7)­(NO<sub>3</sub>)]<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), AgNO3 (15 mg, 0.09 mmol), bipy (28 mg, 0.18 mmol), CH3CN (0.25 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving light yellow crystals of complex 2 overnight. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (15 mg, 24% yield based on U). Anal. Calcd for C54H52­Ag2N10­O18U2: C, 35.62; H, 2.88; N, 7.69. Found: C, 35.69; H, 2.79; N, 7.67%.

[UO<sub>2</sub>Mn­(C7)<sub>2</sub>(phen)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), Mn­(NO3)2·​4H2O (13 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (18 mg, 0.10 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (0.20 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving light yellow crystals of complex 3 within 1 week. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (8 mg, 16% yield based on H2C7). Anal. Calcd for C38H36­MnN4­O10U: C, 45.57; H, 3.62; N, 5.59. Found: C, 45.33; H, 3.54; N, 5.56%.

[NH<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(C7)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>) and [Co­(en)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>2</sub>­[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>12</sub>­(C7)<sub>7</sub>­(O)<sub>4</sub>­(OH)<sub>8</sub>]·​2CH<sub>3</sub>CN·​3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

H2C7 (16 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·​6H2O (35 mg, 0.07 mmol), [Co­(en)3]­Cl3·​3H2O (12 mg, 0.03 mmol), CH3CN (0.20 mL), and demineralized water (0.8 mL) were placed in a 10 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 140 °C under autogenous pressure, giving predominantly large, brick-shaped light yellow crystals of complex 4 mixed with a small amount of very small, lath-shaped darker yellow crystals of complex 5 within 1 month. The solution was filtered while hot, and the crystals were washed with hot water (11 mg, 29% yield based on U if only complex 4 is considered). Anal. Calcd for complex 4, C21H42­N2­O18U2: C, 23.21; H, 3.90; N, 2.58. Found: C, 23.97; H, 3.69; N, 3.63%. The discrepancy in nitrogen content may be due in part to the presence of the small amount of complex 5.

cln_elements.content: Complex 3 is the only one in this series for which magnetic properties have been investigated, since no magnetic interaction is expected between the Ni2+ or Co3+ cations in complexes 1 and 5, respectively. The magnetic properties of complex 3 are those of a dicarboxylato-bridged MnII dimer. The temperature dependence of χM and χM T (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per MnII ion) has been investigated in the 2–300 K range (). At room temperature, χM T is equal to 4.4 cm3 mol–1 K, a value consistent with noninteracting MnII ions (χM T = 4.374 cm3 mol–1 K with g = 2.0). When the temperature is lowered, the χM T value remains constant until 75 K, and it then decreases to 0.5 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The χM value increases on decreasing the temperature from 300 K, and it presents a maximum at 5 K. The shape of these curves is indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the MnII ions. The data were fitted with a simple dimer model where the exchange is represented by the spin Hamiltonian H = −J S 1 S 2. The best fit corresponds to J = −1.2 cm–1 and g = 2.03 [R χT = 9.2 × 10–5 and R χ = 2.0 × 10–4, where R χT = ∑(χcal T – χexp T)2/​∑(χexp T)2 and R χ = ∑(χcal – χexp)2/​∑(χexp)2].
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of Complex 3 

Complex 3 is the only one in this series for which magnetic properties have been investigated, since no magnetic interaction is expected between the Ni2+ or Co3+ cations in complexes 1 and 5, respectively. The magnetic properties of complex 3 are those of a dicarboxylato-bridged MnII dimer. The temperature dependence of χM and χM T (χM being the magnetic susceptibility per MnII ion) has been investigated in the 2-300 K range (). At room temperature, χM T is equal to 4.4 cm3 mol-1 K, a value consistent with noninteracting MnII ions (χM T = 4.374 cm3 mol-1 K with g = 2.0). When the temperature is lowered, the χM T value remains constant until 75 K, and it then decreases to 0.5 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The χM value increases on decreasing the temperature from 300 K, and it presents a maximum at 5 K. The shape of these curves is indicative of a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the MnII ions. The data were fitted with a simple dimer model where the exchange is represented by the spin Hamiltonian H = -J S 1 S 2. The best fit corresponds to J = -1.2 cm-1 and g = 2.03 [R χT  = 9.2 × 10-5 and R χ = 2.0 × 10-4, where R χT  = ∑(χcal T - χexp T)2/∑(χexp T)2 and R χ = ∑(χcal - χexp)2/∑(χexp)2].
